title: How to Get Rid of a Thigh Cramp

steps.title: Figure out which muscle of your thigh is cramping.
steps.content: Figure out which muscle of your thigh is cramping. Before you can treat a thigh cramp with stretching, it’s important to identify which muscle on your thigh is cramping. The thigh has different muscles that can cramp. Identifying which of the major thigh muscles is cramping will help you stretch most effectively. This should typically be done by a healthcare professional, specifically a doctor, physical therapist, or personal trainer. The hamstring runs along the back of the thigh and affects hip and knee movement. The top of the hamstring connects under the gluteus maximus behind the hipbone and ends at the knee. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The quadriceps (often called “the quads”) runs along the front of the thigh and is the major extensor of the knee. The quadriceps is the strongest and leanest muscle of the body. [2] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Stretch out your hamstring.
steps.content: Stretch out your hamstring. If you have a cramp on the back of your thigh, stretch out your hamstring. There are different ways to stretch the hamstring that may help alleviate the cramp. Using a towel or belt, lay flat on the ground and raise the affected leg. Wrap the belt or towel around the back of your thigh, grab the ends of the towel or belt, and gently pull your leg back. [3] X Research source You can use one hand to massage the hamstring as you pull back your leg or wait until you’re finished stretching. If you cannot lie down, try this same stretch with a belt or towel while seated. Sitting with your legs outstretched and simply bending forward has the same effect. Don't strain against the tension of a tight, cramped muscle. Instead, pull very gently. Only increase the stretch as the tension in your leg releases. Consider walking around in between stretches to help relax your hamstring.

steps.title: Stretch out your quads.
steps.content: Stretch out your quads. If you have a cramp on the front of your thigh, stretch out your quad. There is one very effective stretch for the quad that may help alleviate the cramp: Stand up and bend the affected leg up toward your gluteus maximus (butt). If you can, grab your foot and pull it towards your butt for a deeper stretch. Make sure to keep your knee in line with your thigh so that you do not injure the muscles and tendons of your knee. Use one hand to massage the hamstring as you pull your leg toward your butt or wait until you’re finished stretching. Don't strain against the tension of a tight, cramped muscle. Instead, pull very gently. Only increase the stretch as the tension in your leg releases. Walk around in between stretching to help relax your quad.

steps.title: Do some gentle exercises.
steps.content: Do some gentle exercises. Gentle exercises can help stretch out a cramping thigh muscle. General movement will naturally stretch the muscles and also help relax you, but feel free to consider other exercises such as yoga. Only exercise if you are able to, and don’t push yourself when you do. This may only be possible after some light stretching. Try doing yoga, which will also help stretch out the muscle. [4] X Research source Restorative and yin yoga are specifically practiced to help stretch out and repair muscles. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Massage your thigh or get a professional massage.
steps.content: Massage your thigh or get a professional massage. Massage is one of the most effective ways to get rid of a cramp because it increases circulation to the tissues of the muscle. Combined with stretching, massage can quickly alleviate the pain of a muscle cramp while simultaneously relaxing you. [6] X Research source Massage your thigh where the muscle is cramping. Press the area gently with your hands and apply more pressure if it doesn’t hurt. A foam roller is another effective way to massage your thighs. These circular pieces of foam allow you to roll out the affected muscle by applying pressure. You can also get a professional massage to help with thigh cramps. Professional massage is so important as these professionals understand which muscles are affected, but also which muscles are going to have secondary inflammation due to the first injury or cramp. Swedish, neuromuscular, and myofascial release are the most effective types of massage for cramps. Tell the masseuse that you are having problems with cramps so they don’t over-manipulate your muscles. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Use heat to relax your muscles and take the edge off of the pain.
steps.content: Use heat to relax your muscles and take the edge off of the pain. Using heat on a muscle cramp can be an extremely effective way to relax muscle contractions and alleviate pain. [8] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source It may also help you relax, which will minimize tight muscles. From heating pads to warm baths, there are many different types of heat treatments to help get rid of thigh cramps. Taking a warm shower or bath will relax you and help with the pain of a muscle cramp. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Using Epsom salts in a warm bath may also help relieve cramps. Fill a hot water bottle or get a heating pad and place it on the area of your thigh that is cramping. Over-the-counter heat rubs may also help alleviate muscle cramps and relax the affected area.

steps.title: Watch your diet.
steps.content: Watch your diet. There are some studies have shown that low levels of nutrients such as potassium may stimulate muscle cramps. [10] X Research source Be sure to eat enough of these nutrients in your diet, which may minimize how often you experience muscle cramps. Eat bananas and oranges to get potassium. Eat brown rice, almonds, and avocados for magnesium. Calcium is found in yogurt, milk, and other dairy products, as well as in vegetables such as spinach.

steps.title: Hydrate.
steps.content: Hydrate. There are no definitive studies connecting dehydration and leg cramps, but there is some evidence that not drinking sufficient water may contribute to cramping thigh muscles. Making sure that you drink enough water over the course of the day may help you avoid leg cramps. [11] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Drinking water is enough to keep you hydrated. You may prefer something with flavor, so try sports drinks or juices in conjunction with water throughout the day.

steps.title: Sleep on your side and don’t use constrictive bedding.
steps.content: Sleep on your side and don’t use constrictive bedding. Having a tightly made bed can exacerbate the tendency for muscle cramps. [12] X Research source Certain sleeping positions may also contribute to your cramps. By loosening your covers and sleeping on your side, you may avoid thigh cramps. A flat sheet can constrict the ability of your feet and legs to move, so you might want to remove it from your bed. Sleep on one side with your knees slightly bent for optimal conditions to help minimize thigh cramps. Sleeping in positions where your toes are pointing downward may exacerbate cramps. Instead, try to sleep so your feet are either hanging off the end of your mattress or pointed upwards. [13] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Consider pain relievers or muscle relaxants.
steps.content: Consider pain relievers or muscle relaxants. If other methods don’t help your thigh cramp or you have pain that won’t go away, try an over-the-counter pain reliever or prescription muscle relaxant. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you have protracted pain or cramping, though, consult your doctor to rule out an underlying medical condition. Take an NSAID (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs) to reduce any inflammation that may be in the muscle. Talk to your doctor about taking muscle relaxants such as Flexeril (cyclobenzaprine) to help relieve muscle tightness and cramping. [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Do not take quinine.
steps.content: Do not take quinine. Some alternative medicine sources suggest taking quinine for muscle cramps. This treatment can be dangerous and can cause serious health conditions including cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, headaches, and tinnitus, so avoid it if you can. [16] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Figure out the cause of thigh cramps.
steps.content: Figure out the cause of thigh cramps. There are many different causes of thigh cramps, including poor blood circulation and muscle fatigue. Figuring out the cause of your cramp may help you treat it quickly. Poor blood circulation in the legs, magnesium or potassium deficiency, or a pinched nerve can cause thigh cramps. [17] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can treat most thigh cramps with home remedies. For some people, thigh cramps are due to mineral deficiency. Taking a high-quality mineral supplement could be beneficial.

steps.title: Learn what medical conditions can cause thigh cramps.
steps.content: Learn what medical conditions can cause thigh cramps. Not all thigh cramps are attributable to simple factors such as exercising too much or sitting improperly. Certain medical conditions such as Parkinson’s disease or diabetes can make you more likely to get muscle cramps. If home remedies do not alleviate your thigh cramps, see your doctor to make sure you don’t have an underlying condition. Pregnancy can cause thigh cramping. [18] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Cirrhosis of the liver may make your thigh muscles spasm. [19] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Congestive heart failure can cause thigh cramping. [20] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Parkinson’s disease could also cause thigh cramps. [21] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Endocrine disorders such as diabetes can cause thigh cramps. [22] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Osteoarthritis might make your thigh muscles cramp. [23] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Be aware of medications that can cause thigh cramps.
steps.content: Be aware of medications that can cause thigh cramps. Just as certain medical conditions can cause thigh cramps, some medications will make you more prone to these muscle spasms. Knowing which medications can cause cramps can help you or your doctor identify their cause and decide upon the best treatment options. Diuretics such as Lasix can make you more prone to thigh cramping. [24] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Aricept for Alzheimer’s disease may cause thigh cramps. [25] X Research source Procardia for angina and high blood pressure can cause your thigh muscles to cramp. [26] X Research source Tasmar for Parkinson’s disease could cause thigh cramps. [27] X Research source Statin medications for cholesterol such as Crestor and Lipitor may cause thigh cramping.
